Para.Text: Make provision for permanent leave of absence from the House of Lords; to provide for the expulsion of members of the House of Lords in specified circumstances; to make provision for the appointment of a Commission to make recommendations to the Crown for the creation of life peerages; and to restrict membership of the House of Lords by virtue of hereditary peerages.

Be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

P2para.Text: A peer may retire as a member of the House of Lords by giving notice in writing to the Clerk of the Parliaments.
The notice must specify a date from which the retirement is to take effect.
At the beginning of that date the peer ceases to be a member of the House of Lords.
Retirement may not be rescinded.
A peer who does not attend the House of Lords during a Session ceases to be a member of the House at the end of the Session (subject to subsections (2) and (3)).
Subsection (1) does not apply—

P3para.Text: to a peer who has leave of absence in respect of the Session, in accordance with Standing Orders of the House, or
in respect of a Session that is less than six months long.

P2para.Text: Subsection (1) is to be taken to apply to a peer in respect of a Session if, and only if, the Lord Speaker certifies that the peer—

P3para.Text: did not attend at any time during the Session, having regard to attendance records kept by officials of the House, and
did not have leave of absence in respect of the Session.

P2para.Text: In this section a reference to attendance is a reference to attending the proceedings of the House (including proceedings in a Committee of the House or a Joint Committee of the two Houses).
This section applies in respect of the first Session beginning after Royal Assent, and later Sessions.
A peer who is convicted of a serious offence ceases to be a member of the House of Lords (subject to subsections (2) to (5)).
A peer is to be treated as having been convicted of a serious offence if, and only if, the Lord Speaker certifies that the peer has been—

P3para.Text: convicted of a criminal offence by a court in the United Kingdom or elsewhere, and
sentenced or ordered to be imprisoned or detained indefinitely or for more than one year.

P2para.Text: A certificate takes effect on the day on which it is issued.
If the Lord Speaker decides that subsection (2)(a) and (b) no longer apply to a peer by reason of a successful appeal against or challenge to conviction or sentence—

P3para.Text: the Lord Speaker must issue a further certificate to that effect, and
the original certificate under subsection (2) shall be treated for the purposes of this Act as never having had effect.

P2para.Text: The Lord Speaker shall not issue a certificate under subsection (2) in respect of a conviction outside the United Kingdom if the House of Lords resolves that subsection (1) should not apply to the conviction by reason of special circumstances.

P1group.Title: Effect of ceasing to be a member

P2para.Text: This section applies where a peer (whether life or hereditary) ceases to be a member of the House of Lords in accordance with this Act.

The peer becomes disqualified from attending the House of Lords (which includes sitting and voting in the House, and attending proceedings in any Committee of the House or Joint Committee of the two Houses).

Accordingly, the peer shall not receive a writ to attend the House (whether under section 1 of the Life Peerages Act 1958 or by virtue of a hereditary peerage; and a hereditary peer ceases to be excepted from exclusion under
section 2 of the House of Lords Act 1999); and the peer may not attend the House in pursuance of a writ already received.
The peer is not, by virtue of being a peer, disqualified for—

P3para.Text: voting at elections to the House of Commons, or
being, or being elected as, a member of that House.

P2para.Text: A certificate of the Lord Speaker under this Act shall be conclusive for all purposes, and shall not be questioned in a court of law.
A certificate may be issued on the Lord Speaker’s own initiative.
There shall be a Commission (“the Commission”) to make recommendations to the Crown for the creation of life peerages.
No recommendations for the creation of life peerages shall be made other than by the Commission.
All recommendations shall be presented to the Crown by the Prime Minister.
The Commission shall consist of nine members.
The members of the Commission, including the Chairman, shall be nominated jointly by the Speaker of the House of Commons and the Lord Speaker of the House of Lords.
In making nominations under subsection (2), the Speaker and the Lord Speaker shall consult such other persons or bodies as they deem appropriate.

In making nominations, the Speaker and the Lord Speaker shall have regard to the need to ensure that, in respect of members affiliated with registered political parties, the Commission is politically balanced.
At least four of those nominated for membership shall be independent of any registered political party.
The persons nominated under subsection (5) shall include the Chairman of the Commission.
At least four of those nominated shall be Privy Counsellors.
No-one shall be nominated under subsection (5) if at any time in the preceding two years he—

P3para.Text: has been a member of a registered political party;
has given public support, by way of public speaking or appearance, to a registered political party; or
has made a financial donation to any registered political party.

P2para.Text: No-one shall be nominated who is a Minister of the Crown or holder of a national office in any registered political party.
Following nomination by the Speaker and the Lord Speaker under subsection (2), the members shall be appointed by the Crown.
Except as provided for in subsection (12), a member of the Commission shall serve for a non-renewable term of five years.

On the first occasion that the Commission is appointed, three members shall be nominated to serve for a term of four years, three members for a term of five years, and three (including the Chairman) for six years.
A member of the Commission may be removed by the Crown on an address by both Houses of Parliament.

A member of the Commission may resign and in that event, or on the death of a member or on the removal of a member under subsection (13), the member appointed to replace the former member shall serve for the remainder of the term of that former member and may be re-appointed for one further term.

P1group.Title: Commission to determine rules and procedures

P1para.Text: Except as provided for in subsequent sections in this Part, the Commission shall determine its own rules and procedures.

P2para.Text: Proposals for new peers may be made to the Commission by—

P3para.Text: any individual other than those listed in paragraphs (b) and (c) in respect of non-party members (“non-party nominees”);
the leader of any registered political party specified under subsection (2) (“party nominees”); and
the Prime Minister acting as Prime Minister and not as the leader of a registered political party (“prime ministerial nominees”).

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), the Commission shall normally consider nominations made by the Leader of a registered political party that has achieved representation of at least six seats in the House of Commons at the preceding general election.
Any recommendation made by the Commission for the conferment of a peerage shall comply with the criteria specified in this section.
The principal criteria for recommendation for a peerage shall be—

P3para.Text: conspicuous merit; and
a willingness and capacity to make a contribution to the work of the House of Lords.

P2para.Text: The Commission may propose additional criteria as it deems appropriate.
In proposing additional criteria, the Commission shall have regard to the diversity of the United Kingdom population.

The criteria proposed by the Commission under subsection (3) shall be laid before both Houses of Parliament as an order made by statutory instrument by a Minister of the Crown and subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
The criteria shall be not varied other than on a proposal made by the Commission and subject to the procedure specified in subsection (5).

The Commission may propose criteria that relate to an individual or, in the case of proposals made under section 9(1)(a) and (b), the criteria that relate to the balance and diversity that it wishes to achieve.

The Commission may make such enquiry as it considers appropriate to ensure that any person proposed for a peerage fulfils the criteria and it shall be a duty on public bodies to co-operate with any such enquiry.
The Commission may issue guidelines setting out how it will interpret and apply the criteria established under section 10.

The guidelines issued under subsection (1) shall be laid before both Houses of Parliament as an order made by statutory instrument by a Minister of the Crown and subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
The guidelines, once approved, shall be publicised by the Commission in such manner as it deems appropriate.
The guidelines shall not be varied other than by the procedure specified in subsection (2).

P1para.Text: Where the Commission certifies that a person recommended for a peerage meets the published criteria, its certificate shall be conclusive.

P1group.Title: Principles to be followed in making recommendations

P2para.Text: At least once in each calendar year, the Commission must publish, with reasons, proposals for the creation of new peers under section 4(1)(a) and (b), or a proposal that no such creation should be made.
In determining how many new peerages to recommend, the Commission shall have regard to the following principles—

P3para.Text: not less than twenty per cent of the membership of the House of Lords shall consist of members who are independent of any registered political party;
no one party, nor a coalition of parties forming a Government, shall have a majority of members in the House of Lords;

the Government of the day (or in the event of a coalition of parties forming a Government, the largest party in the coalition) shall be entitled to have a larger number of members than the official Opposition, but the majority of that party over the official Opposition
shall normally be no greater than three per cent of the total membership of the House of Lords.

P2para.Text: For the purpose of determining its recommendation under subsection (1), the Commission may consult such persons or bodies as it deems appropriate.

For the purpose of determining the membership specified in subsection (2)(a), a person shall be deemed to be independent of any registered political party if in the two years prior to his nomination for a peerage he—

P3para.Text: was not a member of a registered political party;
had not given public support, by way of public speaking or appearance, to a registered political party; or
had not made a financial donation to any registered political party.

P2para.Text: In giving effect to the principle embodied in subsection (2)(c), the Commission may at its discretion phase in the requisite number of recommendations over a period of two sessions following a General Election.
Subject to the principles embodied in subsection (2), the Commission shall have regard to the need to achieve a membership not exceeding that of the House of Commons.
The Commission shall seek to achieve the membership stipulated in section 7(5) within whichever is the longer of eight years or the course of two full Parliaments.

The members of the House of Lords included for the purpose of calculating the percentage under subsection (2)(a) shall not include the Lords Spiritual or the ex officio members under the terms of the House of Lords Act 1999, but shall include those Lords of Appeal in Ordinary who have ceased to serve in that capacity.

P1group.Title: Party leaders to furnish information to Commission

P2para.Text: Where names are submitted to the Commission by a leader of a registered political party under section 9(1)(b), the leader shall inform the Commission of the procedure and criteria adopted by the party for the purposes of selecting the name for submission.
The Commission shall satisfy itself that the procedure and criteria adopted by a registered political party for the purpose of making nominations are reasonable and consistent.
Leaders of registered political parties submitting names to the Commission shall supply such other information as may be requested by the Commission.
Section 2 of the House of Lords Act 1999 is amended as follows.
For subsection (2) substitute—
No more than 92 people shall be excepted from section 1.
For subsection (4) substitute—
Any vacancy resulting from the death of an excepted person occurring after the coming into force of the House of Lords Reform Act 2013 shall not be filled.
Omit subsection (5).
This Act may be cited as the House of Lord Reform Act 2013.
Parts 1 and 3 of this Act shall come into force at the end of the period of three months beginning with the day on which this Act is passed.
The remaining provisions of this Act shall come into effect on the day on which this Act is passed.
This Act extends to England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
